text:
Riverside Park, north from a point in same, near Tiemann Place and showing tracks of the New York Central Railroad paralleling the North (Hudson) River, with piers and a ferry (Fort Lee, New Jersey) landing at the foot of West 125th Street.

About 1890.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - [Across the North (Hudson) River - Tiemann Place - 125th Street (West).]

text:
Riverside Park: The Ottendorfer Pagoda at W. 135th Street and the North (Hudson) River on the former elaborate Oswald Ottendorfer Estate. This was also known as Eugene Kelleys Kiosk.

1902.

Randall Comfort.

Riverside Park, south from Tiemann Place, (West 127th Street), showing the Claremont Inn on Riverside Drive. This structure was built before the Revolution, on land, sold August 4, 1796, by Nicholas de Peyster to George Pollock, a linen merchant who named the place for its beautiful trees and shrubbery, "Strawberry Hill." His 5 year old son, St. Claire Pollock, fell off the cliffs and was drowned July 15, 1797. His father subsequently went to New Orleans, where his descendants there, are said to be called Polk. His land, expressly reserving the burial place containing the urn of his boy, which may still be seen near Grant's Tomb, was sold in 1803 to Joseph Alston, the husband of Theodosia Burr, who deeded it to Michael Hogan, the former British Consul at Havana. The latter named the place "Claremont" after the residence in Surrey of Prince William, Duke of Clarence, who became King William IV. The Earl of Devon, while living here in 1807, witnessed the trial of Fulton's "Clermont", and in 1815 an occupant was Joseph Bonaparte, the ex-King of Spain. The City finally bought the property, and since 1872 it has been a famous public restaurant. The land to the east and south of same is historical, being the scene of several of the sharpest engagements of the Battle of Harlem Heights on September 16, 1776.

About 1907.

Wurts Brothers.

Riverside Park: A set of 2 views showing Claremont Inn overlooking the Hudson River with the U.S. Fleet thereon. This historic site is at the northern tip of this elongated grassy strip that parallels the river from West 72nd to 125th Streets.

October 13, 1912.

Walter L. Bogert.
title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - Claremont Inn - Between 72nd and 125th Streets (West).

text:
Riverside Park: Two views from the northern extremity of same, across the Hudson River to the Palisades of New Jersey. Laying at anchor amidstream are vessels of the U.S. Navy on display. No. 1 of this set is northward to show the Recreation Pier at the foot of St. Clair (West 129th) Street, while No. 2 shows the Pergola which is the vantage point for No. 1.

May 10, 1915.

Walter L. Bogert.
title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - [Recreation Pier - St. Clair - 129th Street (West).]

text:
Riverside Park: A northward view from West 143rd Street, showing prominently the New York Central Railroad tracks between the Park proper (right) and the North (Hudson) River. The marginal lands will be extended to form a new coastal line.

1917.

Gift of E, M. Jenks.

Riverside Park: Three views westward and southwestward across the Hudson River to the highlands of New Jersey. Amid stream are vessels of the United States Fleet on one of their periodic visits to New York. Photographers vantage point is near Grants Tomb.

June 28, 1919.

Walter L. Bogert.
title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - [The U. S. Fleet near Ulysses S. Grant's Tomb.]

text:
Riverside Park: A set of 3 views in a generally westward direction from a point, near Columbia University's boathouse (about West 115th Street). Through the trees appears a vista of the Hudson River and the palisades of New Jersey. Upon the former appears several vessels of the U.S. Navy.

June 19, 1921.

Walter L. Bogert.

original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:
RIVERSIDE PARK:

(1) Riverside Drive, west side, north from but not including 77th street, showing work being done on the reconstruction of the west side of the "Drive" which is to extend from 72nd to 125th Streets, when completed;

July 11, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, a different angle, and more to the westward, showing reconstruction work in progress on the west side of the "Drive".

July 11, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same locality.

July 11, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Riverside Park, northwestward across the North (Hudson) River from a point in same, near Tiemann Place. Shown at the foot of West 125th Street is a recreation pier and just beyond, the Fort Lee, New Jersey Ferry. In the background appears the new George Washington Bridge.

June 14, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - [Across the North (Hudson) River - Tiemann Place - 125th Street (West).]

text:
Riverside Park: A set of 2 views in a northward direction and showing prominently the New York Central Railroad tracks and yard that occupy the marginal lands between the Park proper and the North (Hudson) River. View No. 1 is northward from 137th Street and No. 2 from 145th Street. This small slope that bears the name Riverside Park is a separate unit from its better known portion and occupies a strip between West 135th and 153rd Streets, being separated by the valley at 125th Street, over which the Drive is carried by a viaduct. In the fall of 1937 the West Side Improvement Project will be completed and a radical change effected in this area. For views of same see files under classification "The West Side Improvement Project!" A publication similarly named was published by the Department of Parks on the opening of same on October 12, 1937.

July 31, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Riverside Drive, east side, south from but not including Tiemann Place, (West 127th Street,) showing the Claremont Inn in the foreground, and the Rockefeller Memorial Church in the background.

June 2, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Riverside Park: A set of 2 views westward from an undetermined point in same across the Hudson River to the Jersey highlands. Shown at anchor amid-stream are the U.S. battleships Tennessee and Pennsylvania in Nos. 1 and 2 respectively.

June 17, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - U. S. battleships.

text:
Riverside Park: A small tots sand pile near West 119th Street. In the center background is General Grants Tomb. This photograph was published by the Department of Parks on the opening of the West Side Improvement Project on October 12, 1937. In comparison to same was shown a Riverside Drive view of 1900 showing bicyclers in the same area; for which see files under that classification.

1937.

Samuel H. Gottscho.
Gift of Department of Parks.
title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - 199th Street
North (Hudson) River - Shore and skyline - Manhattan - 59th Street - George Washington Bridge.

text:
Riverside Park, north from West 135th Street, showing the marginal lands between same and the Hudson River. Traversing this strip are the New York Central Railroad tracks and the new elevated Henry Hudson Parkway, a feature of the vast West Side Improvement Project (q.v.).

To the left is the U. S. Training Ship "Illinois". This formerly was anchored at West 98th Street and only recently was removed here. Across the background is the George Washington Bridge, extending from West 181st Street, Manhattan to the Palisades of New Jersey.

P. L. Sperr

April 1, 1938
Views: 1-2

P. L. Sperr

April 1, 1938
Views: 1-2
